Though you have bestowed the diligence of a letter, I cannot help but cherish the affection of the *tiepao*. If you show kindness to one like me, who would dare forget the source?

I, a latecomer to learning, am ignorant, my childish mind and meager wit adrift in the illusory and indistinct, devoid of radiant and heroic talent. Yet I have already benefited from your nurturing breath and sheltered beneath your canopy. With respect, I arrange these wild geese in formation, reiterating my private plea. Dare I trouble your carriage to grant this heart a fraction of solace?

**A Letter in Reply to Lord Dongcun**

Some ask: The *Record of Lingji Wang* is the king’s own account. If the king has already recorded it, why does he still eagerly seek others? What is his intent?

Among all things between heaven and earth, none is more numinous than the dragon. Its breath transforms, its wonders unfathomable. Yet what it relies upon to manifest its divinity is the cloud. Without clouds, the dragon cannot display its numinous power. This is the meaning behind my request to you.

With respect, I write to express my gratitude.

When Zhang Lu entered the pass, he was already dead. When Ying Hou was at home, Tao Zhu concealed himself. Though Fan Li changed his name repeatedly, his true visage remained that of Gao and Kui. I know not what books Qi studied, but Yao, Shun, Yu, and Tang have transmitted this Dao since antiquity. In haste or turmoil, one must hold fast to it. The subtlest essence lies in grasping the mean—this is the heart behind bequeathing teachings to the world. One must fulfill the rites of honoring parents and serving superiors; for a thousand years, its wonders remain unfathomable. Ninety-four transformations may be heard of, but without form or sound, I dare not answer the questions of ghosts and spirits.

To take righteousness as profit is not the way of the bandit Zhi. Though I possess only mediocre talent, I harbor a lingering attachment. Though the Three Rivers do not respond, a single phrase suffices to convey understanding. Why have you come? There is a reason.

One chaste woman shames the wanton crowd; one capped man humbles the topknotted nine. Though this is the way of the world, does it still possess humaneness? Not illuminating the *Great Learning*’s generation of wealth brings deep disgrace to the *Spring and Autumn*’s forthright brush. In this age, who but you could shoulder this task?

Though one may not be human, humanity is not heaven. One must act in accordance with words, and speak in accordance with deeds.

I reverently consider Lord Dongcun, whose virtue bridges the hidden and the manifest, whose Dao spans the obscure and the luminous. On paper, his clouds and mist evoke the structure of Liu’s bones and Yan’s flesh; in his breast, the vast ocean contains nothing but the sentiments of Zhou and the thoughts of Confucius. Thus, he recognizes today’s right as yesterday’s wrong. Never has there been a case where A approves and B disapproves.

A single word carries weight, upheld by the consensus of many. Why seek outward traces when this is already a matter of subtle influence?

Lord Beishan has sons, grandsons, and generations beyond. —*Postscript by Lord Xiecun*

I am honored by your fine composition, which brings radiance to our ancestral shrine. Reading it again and again, I am suddenly struck with insight. Truly, this is what is meant by "whether wise or unwise, the difference is as great as thirty *li*." If I were to compare myself to Master Tongchuan, that would be beyond my daring. Yet I shall place your *Dao Inscription* by my seat, so that future visitors to this hall may read these words, envision your person, and—like seeing a tiger’s pelt—know the roar that once shook the mountain forests and made all beasts tremble.

—*Letter from Lord Xiecun*

Recalling the poems you sent in your sleeve, I remember our brief encounter, where I glimpsed but half your refined bearing. Now, entrusted with composing this record, I behold once more your extraordinary presence—fivefold in its brilliance. Though I long to sweep the path before your gate, I have not yet had the chance. To hold the whip as your attendant would be to gaze upon a towering mountain. My heart holds you in deepest esteem; to know you is to meet Jingzhou—just as I have always wished. Not to have encountered the Lord of Lu is simply fate.

I reverently consider Your Honor, the Prefectural Judge, a man of our native district, advanced in years yet blessed with the vitality of Shao, his hidden virtues sustained by divine favor. His mastery of the classics and cultivation of conduct embody the legacy of the Duke of Zhou’s descendants. His wealth enriches the state, surpassing the achievements of Yan Ying and Guan Zhong. His learning and scholarship surpass others, while his official rank is but a secondary matter. Having found joy in the company of Lord Dongcun, why should he not also wander the wilds?

I dare to bow in humble reverence, grateful to have found recognition in this day. The inscription for the shrine is elegant, its thousand words a testament to refinement. Already, it circulates among the people, its praise enduring for generations, all flowing from your breast. This is no mere carved dragon on paper; even my crude and rustic talent cannot grasp the force of your acclaim. The numinous responds, and the village shrine shines with splendor.

A gentleman forgives others’ shortcomings; even the smallest gift carries weight, its intent as light as a goose feather yet spanning a thousand *li*. I humbly present this pair of carp as a token of my diligence. Your words are worth a thousand gold, and in return, I offer this white goose in gratitude. Deeply ashamed of my rough draft, I can only hope for your indulgence. I respectfully command my ink-brush scribe to gaze upon the thousand volumes of history.

—*Letter on Behalf of the Local Community from Lord Xiecun*

Han Zihua was praised by the Duke of Holding the State—this is the honor due a scholar-official of our time. Xie Lingyun never dreamed of Hui Lian; how then could he have composed those sublime lines by the pond? Where there is such a brother, there must be such a spirit. I revere the man, and thus I revere the deity.

You have deigned to lower yourself to one so unworthy, a great talent bestowing favor. Long have I cherished your humility and virtue, never daring to forget your kindness. All say that the elder brother’s judgment is sound, yet it is truly your guidance that steers us. After three years of offering, I lament my own inadequacy. Even a meager meal, once spoken of by you, gains weight. How dare I borrow a thousand gold? Yet your praise, like the words of a trusted friend, moves me deeply.

I reflect that I have idled in my village, retreating to the mountains. Though poor, I have never changed my countenance. Wherever my gourd bowl has taken me, I have never presumptuously presented my name. Long have I basked in the lingering grace of your river’s bounty, bound as we are by the vines of kinship. Beyond this, I have no other requests, nor do I know what else to do.

I reverently consider you, a man of renowned lineage, a rare talent of our age. Your breast brims with noble aspirations, your brush flows with vast and boundless prose. I am deeply ashamed that my humble gate cannot accommodate a carriage of four horses. I respectfully offer this letter with utmost reverence, though I am unworthy even of its paper and ink.

Your many acts of kindness have long been known, and I have heard of your reputation as a military adjutant. The temple’s renewal is entirely due to the efforts of Governor Yu. This fulfills my wishes, and I offer these words in gratitude.

—*Letter to Commander Zhang*

I prostrate myself in awe, considering how your bold arguments in the court have secured a legacy for a thousand autumns, and how your strategies within the command tent have earned you the enfeoffment of ten thousand households. Your exemplary conduct endures, ensuring prosperity for generations to come. I dare to present my name, seeking an audience before the court. Your humble inquiries are without shame, and the songs of the people attest to your virtue.

I reverently consider Your Honor, the Commander-in-Chief, whose *qi* is vast and unyielding, whose nature embraces benevolence. You govern the people with a parent’s heart and judge affairs with divine clarity. Grievances vanish like thorns cleared from the thicket, while virtuous deeds flourish like sweet pear trees. Your upright governance stands unmatched among the seven prefectures of southern Min. Your noble bearing soars above all, and all gaze upon you as the North Star among men.

Your learning is as deep as the ocean, your scholarship as splendid as the blossoms of the literati. Your brush wields creation itself, conjuring wind and clouds upon the page. Long have I heard of the two peerless talents in your court, and I rejoice in this gathering of shared culture. Your legal acumen rivals that of Cui and Du, still praised to this day. Your critiques of Ou and Yu leave no room for reproach. The gates of your hundred-*li* city stand magnificent, and the thousand-year-old ornamental pillars are renewed.

How admirable! How excellent! I prostrate myself in reflection: I am but a child from a remote village, born in a thatched hut, yearning to behold the pure light of wind and moon, having once sat in the lingering glow of rivers and streams. Now, in this village of accumulated virtue, there stands an old rain-praying temple, repeatedly blessed with divine responses, known as the Spiritually Efficacious Shrine. Its characters are as large as pecks, boldly inscribed and doubly cherished. The inscription is on every tongue, and gratitude for your virtue must be sung anew. This is a grand affair for all time—who would dare to diminish its legacy?

These empty formalities in a wooden box are hardly worthy as gifts. May heaven bless and support you with abundant fortune, fulfilling the sincerity of my prayers. With humble shame and heartfelt gratitude, I offer these words.

—*Letter Requesting an Inscription for the Temple Gate from the Surveillance Commissioner*

The arrival of your carriage in the eight prefectures brings added luster to this blessed land. The Surveillance Bureau, with its solemn governance, extends the protection of heaven itself. I am deeply moved and will never forget this kindness.

I reverently consider Your Honor, the Surveillance Commissioner, a rare talent of our age, a great virtue for our time, whose nature is pure and conduct meticulous. Long has your family been renowned as upright officials in Chengdu. Your heart is upright and your intentions sincere, having personally received the teachings of Master Yichuan. Your lineage has long been praised for its purity, passing down exemplary conduct to your descendants. You uphold the customs of Guān and Luò, making ritual and righteousness the model for Ōu and Mǐn.

Your calligraphy stands unmatched through the ages, your brushwork sweeping away a thousand armies. Lu, Luo, Wang, and Yang are hardly worth mentioning; Ōu, Yu, Chu, and Xue cannot compare.

Truly, your brilliance shines like a beacon, and I humbly submit the sincerity of my earnest devotion.

I reflect with reverence upon myself—a rustic commoner, a humble scholar of the fields, narrow in vision and small in stature, my person attached to ignorance and folly. Yet daring to lift my gaze toward the axe and halberd of your judgment, I venture to present this petition with bowed head.

Here in this village of accumulated virtue stands the ancient Lingji Palace, a sanctuary revered by all the people, where prayers for rain and sunshine have long been answered. I now seek but three characters, though they weigh more than a thousand gold. If you would graciously bestow your wisdom early, my joy would be boundless.

Your Honor’s gate is vast, and I dare once more to present this humble offering, hoping it may reflect even a glimmer of your luminous example. I, a mere well-frog with a child’s understanding, have consulted the oracle again, my ignorance twice over. I can only hope you might deign to consider it, though I cannot fathom the depth of your judgment.

On behalf of the villagers, I present this petition for the Dao’s flourishing at Lingji Palace:

Lingji Palace—what a sacred precinct! A thousand years of incense smoke.
The marketplace of blue cloth teems with people; generations of noble lineages gather.
With shared devotion, we seek to adorn it.
May its august title be honored in the two capitals, its glorious name resound across the four directions.

The writings of later masters that transform the present—those of Wang, Yang, Lu, and Luo—cannot surpass this. Ascending to transcendence and verifying sagehood, the teachings of Zheng, Qiao, Wo, and Quan—might one yet hear of them? With the heart set on carrying forth Heaven’s transformative work and the vow sworn to benefit beings and aid others, compassion manifests in myriad forms, and merits defy measure.

The rites of spring sacrifices endure in their observance, yet the duty of morning and evening devotions may lack its proper steward. Thus, through inertia, we have failed to seek out worthy ones. Who, dwelling alone, might deliberate on the Great Harmony? He who takes goodness as his teacher—such as you, sir, a man of aligned resolve and disciplined conduct—commands the collective plea of the multitude, not for my own sake or out of personal favor.

Should you deign to grace us with your presence, the grandeur of the palace gates would shine all the brighter. Again, as iron is transmuted into gold, we rely deeply on your refining power; as a brick cast forth draws forth jade, we bear the weight of your parallel prose. In my recent memorial, I humbly presented a stern simplicity, my gaze fixed on the smallest details, and now, with reverence, I sweep clean my humble abode, awaiting your arrival with hands clasped, ready to receive your radiance with offerings of incense and flowers.

A thousand-year-old marble pillar, home to the swift-returning crane of immortals. A ten-thousand-year Dao sanctuary, a land as majestic as the Six Turtles of antiquity. From all directions, the gaze of the world turns here; by the strength of the many, it is sustained. To manage it, to cultivate it—whose effort is this? From beginning to end, though it be my heart, it is the heart of the villagers. Yet I fear this flourishing may not long endure, and so, with earnest devotion, I make this plea.

Human sentiment is thorough: they say the plum blossoms by the stream are worth a thousand gold. To see this good work completed would surpass even the wealth of Yangzhou’s ten thousand taels. I humbly request that the High Master Tang Zong establish ten thousand assemblies to assess and honor this endeavor. As the assembly of gods and humans spreads its blessings, your name shall suddenly emerge, summoned forth. With respectful deference, I await your esteemed presence.

I hold in deepest reverence so-and-so, a master whose learning flows from profound sources, whose Dao towers like a mountain peak. You grasp the subtlest mysteries of the profound and empty, embodying stillness and non-action. Your mind upholds the strictness of ritual purification, and your strength bolsters the gates of the teaching. From the first, I trusted in your conduct among men. In this age, who but you could lead?

Now, for the sake of Lingji Palace, we propose a Universal Salvation Assembly, to be held on the fifteenth day of the seventh month, with a special ten-day observance. Three days of fasting will precede the nine-morning rites. Externally, the teachings will be expounded; internally, the *Scripture of Salvation* will be recited. I implore you to condescend to your exalted station and preside over the ritual proceedings. Should the souls of the departed find deliverance, this assembly will indeed be illuminated. Looking up, I rely on your wisdom; bowing low, I risk overstepping.

I, dwelling in rustic obscurity, am but a latecomer—what do I know? Though the Dao may be beyond my hearing, the virtuous delight in doing good. Should you graciously descend from your carriage to take your seat, I shall sweep the mat to welcome you. A single boat can ferry one sixty *li*; I shall forever prepare incense for your long journey. Countless people turn to you in devotion—joining the multitude, I shall not be cast aside.

---

On behalf of the villagers, I petition for the appointment of a lecturer to the capital:

For long have I admired your noble character, not merely for a day. Recently, in discussing the mysteries, I presumptuously knocked at the gate of your cinnabar chamber. You deigned to respond with humility, casting your gaze upon me. Since our parting, this sentiment has never waned.

Now, for the construction of the ritual platform at Lingji Palace, I have conveyed this humble request, entreating you to condescend to travel here. When it comes to the literary style of canonical texts, you are the one the people have chosen. In this age of moral exemplars, who but you could lead? Should you apply the fasting rituals as your own practice, enabling our deities to merge with the likenesses of immortals, how profound would be the blessings bestowed!

The timber of the ridgepole and the pillars of the threshold are not your proper place. Like the vastness of rivers and seas, all streams—even the muddy and stagnant—find their way to you. Should you deign to descend to the altar, I shall hold the broom in readiness.

---

A petition for the appointment of Yue Shan as temple warden:

I, who respond to circumstances to benefit beings, have yet to open the gate of skillful means. Pushing aside the grasses to seek the mysteries, I long to behold the depths of true emptiness. You have graciously taken notice of me, yet for long I have proffered my card in vain, blocked by the long barrier of the western gorge, gazing toward the northern mountains in yearning. Now, having received your command, how dare I not act as your humble disciple?

The divine and enlightened cannot be fathomed—this petty one shall do his best to respond. Were it not for the precepts of the Venerable Master Chonggui, how could Pang the Layman display his spiritual powers? The *Record of the Pavilion of Great Compassion* is now complete; I dare to reveal my Eastern Slope visage. The Dao sanctuary of Caoxi is no small matter—why not take up the Sixth Patriarch’s koan?

Why has the Venerable Master Chonglin come? The Old Man of the Stone Path will surely not cast me aside. Fearing that the golden root may be misaligned, I still seek the jade axe to refine it. Should you deign to take this as your topknot and robe, it would be like moving an old case to this neglected thatch. I offer but a cluster of gourds and a bolt of fine silk, a modest gift like the purple bamboo shoots of Huzhou.

May your Dharma eye open wide; my private sentiments need not be spoken.

---

A congratulatory address on the appointment of Lu Shan:

...

Humbly I recall how the Venerable Master of Guangshun once ascended the jade steps of the imperial court, and how the Xiantong Chan Monastery was graced with the honor of a golden edict and inscribed plaque. What has shone before must surely return in its beginning.

With reverence I consider the Venerable Master of White Deer: the world is drenched in his Dharma rain, the fragrance of compassion fills the rocky cliffs—truly a superior person, blessed with the marks of virtue and power. I look up in awe at the boundless imperial favor, and bow in respect at the proclamation of his appointment. Scaling the lofty peak, he climbs the clouded heavens of the ten thousand years; his voice resounds, "Long live the Emperor!" The great monastery adorns the blessed land of the Three Mountains. His renown weighs upon the Three Mountains, and with a shout he scatters the wild foxes beyond the fields. Joyfully encountering the pair of deer before the hall, the monastic groves stand in solemn order, and the neighboring villages gleam with splendor.

I reflect that I, in my humble station, am without ability, though our bond has long been established. How dare I, with my insubstantial and empty words, venture to approach the wondrous workings of his spiritual powers? Though his name is inscribed upon the pagoda and his writings manifest in his deeds, yet in advancing step by step, his strength surpasses others. Since the Dharma’s cause is no mere accident, the Dao sanctuary will naturally flourish. I now offer my congratulations, never forsaking compassion. Having been graced by the honor of his elephant-borne visitation, I pray he may reveal the sacred auspice of the green waterfowl. For a thousand years, this temple must receive the Buddha’s confirmation. With a single wisp of heart’s incense, one ought to join palms in reverence.

My written words are few, but my devotion runs deep. I humbly present this verse:

Upon the rain-drenched peak he sits,
His wondrous powers vast and deep.
Rejoicing in the weight of royal grace,
His name soars high o’er Ten-Thousand-Year Peak.

*Postscript of Inquiry by Zhou Shenggong*

This Zhou Shenggong is the finest of our hometown—a true "white eyebrow." The common saying goes, "Scholars are often ill-fated," and indeed it rings true. His four-six parallel prose seeks some response, yet this is beyond even my three-fold experience; I can only reply with a few brief points.

All mountains, forests, rivers, valleys, and hills are called *shen*—spirits—yet the Three Offerings hold particular solemnity in the rites. When yin and yang, wind and rain, brightness and darkness lose their proper rhythm, the Six Excesses are already warned against in medical texts. Ashamed of my lack of the mountain spirit’s efficacy, I have instead invited the river demon’s mockery, left speechless and unable to defend myself. What transgression have I committed? One may discern the truth in the end, yet might not misfortune and fortune still confound?

The tortoise does not weary of me; I rely solely on the first divination’s omen. The horse cannot speak, yet I dare inscribe the words "peace" in seal script. The yellow bear appears in dreams—dreams born of thought. The red snake transforms into a shadow—yet even shadows may be doubted.

These are all the toils of spirit and thought, leading to calloused hands and feet. The illness, long afflicted by frost and dew, is a calamity without cause. The moon now lodges in *Dou* and *Niu*—whose fault is this? If Heaven wills it, what can be done about fate?

As the common saying goes, "The Master does not speak of the uncanny." Yet I have humbly received the brush’s sharp reproach, and deeply shamed the wooden scholar’s lack of letters. Forty-nine years of delusion—only now do I glimpse Qu Boyu’s regret. Twelve thousand breaths of *qi*—yet never have I heard the name of Wang Shuhe.

I would rise from nine deaths to a single life’s remnant, to master the teachings of *Yongming’s* seven charts and eight wrappings. Though a hundred medicines have been tried in hope of some chance success, if even one man remains unhealed, it is called your failure. Why must you overturn and declare, "There is that which stands with Heaven and rains upon Earth"? The people of Yue revere reproach; the people of Chu revere ghosts—can their customs not be changed? The *Wei* stomach’s obstruction, the *Qi* stomach’s blockage—what use are those physicians?

Having not repeated the same error, I may yet take one more journey. I regularly rub the jade sphere—who reads the *Heji Jue*? Moreover, the parallel prose of four-six rhythms is itself a masterpiece.

Having consulted the oracle again and again, I glimpse at last the true circumstances. There comes a time when no medicine is needed—yet how can brush and ink suffice to record it? Your prayers have been long and earnest; what more could you say? Since your kindness has pressed me so, I cannot refuse.

Though the broken-arm prophecy proved true, it did no harm to the benevolence of Yang Shu. Though the lost-axle kin were unharmed, it did not diminish the renown of Lou Shide. Twice have I sent letters of mourning, each time shamed by your commands. Though a gentleman may grieve in adversity, must he assume the guise of a petty man?

If Heaven does not summon me back, what can Bo Liao do against fate? For great renown must endure the trials of the altar’s pit, and dark spirits often rise in the wake of lingering illness. What crime has the crane committed? When will the phoenix’s forging be complete? Even a lame tortoise may yet take one more journey; the bedridden rooster can still reconnect. Yet I fear the mockery of “washing feet and losing wealth,” and dread the reproach of “extending a hand only to cast the next stone.”

Since you have spoken to me so earnestly, I recall your footsteps with joy. To repay enmity with virtue—even the old fist finds no surfeit. Strive in learning and conduct, and may you never forget your former steps. To share another’s sorrows and rejoice in their joys—even Confucius and Mencius found this hard to articulate. To drown where others drown, to hunger where others hunger—this was the vow of Yu and Ji.

To skillfully save all things is to waste nothing. To speak when one can speak is to never misspeak. To seek a six-foot vine, one must first cultivate three-year mugwort.

My reply, written in haste, still harbors the fear of a bladder’s rupture. I would rush out in bare feet to welcome you, yet wait for your carriage’s arrival. I raise my whip in gratitude—why hesitate to follow in your steps?

**Marriage Proposal for the White-Water Bridge Alliance**
I recall that our two families, having borne sons as clever as paired fish, now unite for a second generation. The oracle confirms the harmony of the mating phoenix. The Zhus and Chens share an old bond; the Zhengs and Weis renew a long affection. We pledge by the green mountains and swear by the white waters. The karmic cause is now fulfilled—how fortunate we are!

Moreover, your granddaughter’s virtue follows the legacy of her forebears, delighting in the zither’s charm like Bian of old. My grandson, raised on poetry and books, has yet to wield his brush to compose. Though this is a matter of kinship, why should age be a barrier? She may serve as Huang’s matchmaker, and all will call her the true wife of Liang.

Speak of love only when the time is right, offering fern and artemisia in dutiful service. As rites value simplicity, I humbly prepare hazelnuts and chestnuts to announce the betrothal. My modest gifts are listed on the right—with respect, I present this proposal for your consideration. May your esteemed kindness deign to reflect upon it.

**Raising the Ridgepole Address**
As the Three Mountains converge, all proclaim this blessed land of great peace. From a single vein of lineage, the Dao’s gate follows the hidden path. Now, entrusted with the duty of the ancestral hall, we complete the work of building a home. The oracle and tortoise shell align with the auspicious hexagram; the people’s fondness for magpies and crows manifests as omens upon the roof.

With reverence, I consider [Name], who carries on the family legacy, his name sung in praise. In his hand, the jade tablet emerges from the brush’s artistry; in his heart, he holds the framework’s grand design. From a single household’s affairs, we rejoice in the splendor of the twin-petal tower. Sheltered within a hundred *li*, we celebrate the glory of the flowery county.

One day’s renewal brings ten thousand years of magnificence. As a humble craftsman, I dare not claim great wisdom. Following the given path, I plan and construct—how could I presume to saw or hew at will? In the marketplace of gold, they vie to boast of Fan Li’s wealth. Before the hall of colorful robes, I wish to emulate Lao Lai’s play.

Let me offer the sparrow’s modest congratulations for the new hall, and ascend the rainbow’s high ridgepole. As the poem says:
*Like you, the timber is fit for ridgepole and beam—*
*Yet it still requires skillful carving.*
*A great mansion shelters ten thousand, vast in its refuge,*
*And in the courtyard, we rejoice in the triple sophora’s shade.*

**End of Xu Xian’s Literary Anthology, Scroll Thirteen**
**Xu Xian’s Literary Anthology, Scroll Fourteen**

**Lamp Couplets for the Ridgepole**

**Ridgepole Couplets**
For this palace:
May the sagely lord’s myriad-year Dao forever bring peace to the Central Lands,
May the luminous spirits’ singular virtue bestow blessings upon the state and household.

The phoenix’s fortune stretches long, eternally inscribing ten thousand years of prosperity,
The turtle-mountain’s grandeur stands firm, safeguarding the four borders in everlasting peace.

Renewing the old to restore the grand design,
When adversity reaches its peak, fortune returns—kindred aspirations are fulfilled.

**Hall of Fixed Light**
The Buddha’s compassion pervades the three thousand great thousand worlds,
Divine power, vast and boundless, protects the temple halls for ten thousand ages.

**Temple of the Rain-Praying King**
May the sagely Son of Heaven’s life endure as long as heaven and earth, his sacred longevity boundless,
May the Rain-Praying King bring timely rains and gentle winds—his divine spirit ever responsive.

**Celebratory Lamp Couplets**
May the emperor’s reign span ten thousand years, as enduring as the seas and mountains,
May the realm’s eight directions be open and connected, its carts and books sharing the same Dao.

May the sagely lord’s longevity be ever secure, the Southern Dipper’s star presenting auspicious signs,
May the divine radiance appear thrice, the Eastern Marchmount’s eight characters shining brighter.

When the august one establishes the ultimate standard, heaven and earth follow the four seasons’ order,
When great virtue is called "life," the people are nurtured and the five grains ripen.

The sage possesses great virtue—longevity, wealth, and many sons,
The world becomes one family, its borders well-governed, its seas united.

The imperial capital’s splendor coils like a dragon, crouches like a tiger, its might weighing ten thousand jun,
The realm enjoys great peace—barking dogs and crowing roosters resound across the four seas.

Our dynasty unifies all from north to south, heaven vast and earth broad,
The world knows peace once more, customs refined and winds pure as in ancient times.

A flourishing era of civil brilliance—this is the time of great peace,
Bountiful harvests of fine grain bring joy to the eastern farmers in this year of plenty.

**Golden Palace’s Birthday Celebration**
The Golden Palace’s transformation body manifests eighty-two forms, all sharing the same name and title,
A jade goblet offers longevity—sixteen thousand years become spring and autumn.

Penglai is entirely home to immortals, their names inscribed on the cinnabar terrace,
The Southern Dipper’s Old Man Star appears, its light joining the Eastern Well.

**Jade Palace’s Birthday Celebration**
On the great celebration of the seventh month’s Zhongyuan,
Five winds and ten rains mark a time of peace, jade candles present auspicious signs.

Heaven-born ministers yield to Lord Lai, granting him a day’s precedence,
Thunderous cheers echo Zhuangzi’s eight-thousand-autumn blessing.

Five-colored auspicious clouds appear in splendid omens,
Triple harvests bring joy in celebrating great peace.

The Jade Palace’s clouds part, heaven lies close at hand,
The Silver River’s waters bathe the moon in clear radiance.

Heaven’s seal is written in cinnabar phoenix script,
Earth’s grandeur rises in the towering turtle-mountain.

**Hall of Harmonious Kinship**
Baskets and stands preserve the Zhou rites,
Robes and caps restore the Han’s majestic bearing.

Lofty integrity and perfect reputation shine like the sun,
A hall filled with harmonious qi is a single sphere of spring.

Literature is an eternal endeavor,
Loyalty and filial piety are a lifetime’s devotion.

Reputation endures like the sun and moon,
Dao and righteousness weigh as heavily as mountains.

The divine tree remains evergreen,
The cinnamon tree delights in passing on its fragrance.

**Hall of Childbirth**
Immortal consorts gather at the Jasper Pool feast,
Men must study the jade-slab classics.

The thousand-year peach of the Dark Garden presents auspicious signs,
The ten-thousand-year cassia of Yan Mountain transmits its fragrance.

Mulberry and catalpa share the shade of the village shrine,
Orchids and irises flourish abundantly in the courtyard.

The family legacy is passed down through generations,
A single arrow strengthens the resolve of sons.

**Celebrating the Lantern Festival Couplets**
Heaven unfolds the phoenix calendar—may the nation and altars endure for ten thousand years,
Earth embraces the turtle-mountain—lanterns and towers illuminate the fifteenth night.

On the Lantern Festival’s radiant evening, carriages and horses bring three thousand guests,
The turtle-mountain’s resplendent decorations crown the southeast’s foremost peak.

Ten thousand bushels of lotus lanterns—towers and the night moon’s shadows intertwine,
Three coins for a peck of rice—village shrines and spring winds bring joy to the people.

Penglai’s three isles, where immortals dwell—palaces here are noble,
The Eastern Wall’s two stars, repository of texts—the Milky Way’s literary splendor.

The ancestral temple’s solemn rites have been observed for four hundred years,
The first month’s harmony begins on the fifteenth night—the Lantern Festival’s feast and revelry.

The sun’s brilliance adorns banners with golden characters,
Clouds part at the heavenly gates, revealing the jade brush’s radiance.

Temple sacrifices preserve ancient rites for a thousand years,
Proclamations of honor are inscribed in lavish gold script.

**Lamp Couplets**
The Perfected Lord receives the register—may the emperor’s longevity match heaven and earth’s endurance,
The Heavenly Master’s Dao is revered—may the sun and moon shine brightly for a hundred generations.

The sagely lord ushers in great peace—may his life rival the Southern Mountains, his blessings flow like the Eastern Sea,
The immortal Dao remains ever auspicious—his name inscribed on the cinnabar terrace, his body dwelling in the Red City.

The jasper palaces’ twin towers stand a foot from heaven, ascending the cloud ladder with ease,
A golden missive arrives from the sun’s edge, its radiance outshining the stars.

Purified through fasting and bathing, serve the Supreme Emperor with an undivided heart,
"Intelligent, bright, upright, and correct"—such is the spirit that receives its due virtue.

The purple clay proclaims the imperial decree, displaying the divine radiance of new honors,
Blue cloth forms the net of talismans—ancient prophecies and figures in lavish splendor.

**Universal Salvation Ritual**
May the present emperor’s reign endure for ten thousand years, his power as stable as bedrock,
May the Primordial Heavenly Worthy expound the scriptures ten times, his light manifesting in precious pearls.

Mount Tai stands majestic, the four peaks’ revered site—fasting for a single day,
The Great Canopy stretches boundless above the three realms—universally delivering all beings.

The divine capital spans eighteen thousand miles, the four lands coming to pay homage,
The seventy-two bureaus of Mount Tai deliver all beings.

A single yellow cloud congeals in the spirit’s abode,
Three thousand measures of sweet dew universally open the gates of salvation.

May the sagely lord’s life equal heaven’s, the cosmos enduring for ten thousand generations,
May Laozi take the Dao as his foundation, the four directions’ sun and moon ever bright.

**Couplets for the Lonely Spirits’ Lamps**
The Eastern Wondrous Severity Palace manifests transformations across the ten directions, light revealing auspicious signs,
The Western Na Kingdom’s Maitreya and Great Brahma vow to deliver all beings.

Purified through fasting and bathing, serve the Supreme Emperor with an undivided heart,
The departed souls ascend directly to the Southern Palace, attaining the wondrous Dao.

On the Jade Capital Mountain, heaven lies but a foot and a half away, piercing straight through the Dark Capital,
The Ganges’ sands span the earth—all worlds together ride the wondrous Dao.

The Great Canopy stretches boundless above the three realms, the nine qi swirling and dense,
Mount Tai stands majestic, the four peaks’ revered site—ten thousand spirits come to pay homage.

A single pearl the size of a millet grain—ten directions’ worlds together behold its light,
Several cases of jade scriptures—hundreds of ancestors and ten thousand generations all receive deliverance.

The Eastern Florescence’s pure realm, the Western Na Kingdom—upholding precepts and practicing fasting,
The Southern Prosperity’s high office, the Northern Capital’s Cold Pool—saving the living and delivering the dead.

A single libation of cool, sweet dew,
Ninefold mysteries ascend the Upper Clarity’s thoroughfare.

Eight colors and nine chapters reveal the wondrous Dao,
Hundreds of ancestors and ten thousand generations ascend the Vermilion Palace.

The three paths of suffering are liberated, transcending the three realms,
Eight-colored radiance illuminates the eight directions.

Hearing the scriptures and listening to the Dharma, together we arouse compassion,
Sharing food and clothing, all equally enjoy warmth and sustenance.

The Blood Bowl Assembly—Mulian repays his mother’s kindness, his filial piety reaching through heaven and earth, his divine powers unmatched;
Earth Treasury presides as Teaching Master, his Dharma pervading the worlds as numerous as the sands of the Ganges, the Three Thousands.

*Xu Xian’s Literary Gems, Scroll Fourteen concludes*

chunks.original_text: 梁灯联 梁联 庆贺灯联 庆元宵灯联 灯联 孤魂所灯联 徐仙翰藻跋 #1按此目录原有脱误。 今已据正文校正，不复详注。 徐仙翰藻 经名：徐仙翰藻。 元人陈梦根编集。 十四卷。 底本出处：《万历续道藏》 徐仙翰藻卷之一 灵济祖庙记 灵济祖庙，夫祖者，言其始也。 予姓徐，乃偃王之后，世仕唐。 及五季乱，奉天子命守金陵。 晋开运二年乙巳，闽王王氏阅墙之虋，兵革肆兴，予遂将查、边等骑万人，投建州。 明年，掇福州，间道西峡，将梯鹿岭，由南台县取漳泉。 乡之胡者，叩马而前曰：适有溃兵牿乱，为民之仇不图。 今日复见王师，王若闵其不辜，吹而苏之，不至跋蟦，德莫大焉。 军驻而成列，教子商子搏力，法嘬其锋。 贼死咋，民获喘。 汗师还，耆老犹作绨袍恋恋之意。 子以李御史常容之数，马上策之，知与若等从事之期。 待来年矣，果脱化於钩伍间。 精魂不爽，降而为神，于鳖峰之阳。 其初未有祠，制草其庐，木其炉。 岁时伏、腊，祀事罔缺。

**Scroll One of Xu Xian’s Elegant Compositions**

**Record of the Lingji Ancestral Temple**
The term "ancestor" speaks of origins. My surname is Xu, descendant of King Yan of Xu, a lineage that served the Tang dynasty. When the Five Dynasties fell into chaos, I received the Son of Heaven’s command to guard Jinling. In the second year of Kaiyun of the Jin (945 CE), the Min king Wang’s internal strife erupted into war. I then led cavalry commanders Zha, Bian, and ten thousand riders to defect to Jianzhou. The following year, I seized Fuzhou, took the western path through the Xi gorge, scaled the Deer Ridge, and advanced from Nantai County to capture Zhang and Quan. A villager surnamed Hu knelt before my horse and said: "Just now, routed soldiers wrought havoc, becoming the people’s unforeseen enemy. Today, we behold the royal army once more. If Your Lordship pities their innocence and revives them with a breath, sparing them from calamity, no virtue could be greater."

The troops halted and formed ranks. I instructed my sons Shang and Bo to join forces and, by military discipline, blunt the enemy’s assault. The rebels perished in battle, and the people found respite. When the army withdrew, the elders still harbored the lingering affection of *tiepao*. I pondered Li Yushi’s counsel on leniency and, from horseback, devised a plan, knowing the time had come to act with them. The following year, I indeed escaped transformation amid the snares of the ranks. My spirit, undiminished, descended to become a deity upon the southern slope of Biefeng. Initially, there was no temple—only a thatched hut and a wooden incense burner. Yet during the seasonal sacrifices of *Fu* and *La*, the rites were never neglected.

chunks.original_text: 宋太平兴国八年癸未春不雨，种未入土，啬夫用虞。 二月初，吉戊子卜於予。 习吉祠之前有潭，旁衮四五丈，深不可测。 倏有云气飞腾，竟日不散。 翌日昧爽，烈风、雷电、雨雹交至，人大悦。 越三日，哉生明诣祠求答，目其祠，荡为洪水之墟。 且怪且疑，遂辨香沉诸潭而祝之。 忽有木炉捧出水心，香灰不湿，信有神物。 须臾双龙蟠远，扶翼而西流，直至传筑屿中，山横溪而不进。 屿中旧号香炉峰。 乌鹊飞呼，将有所迎。 纸钱结界，异香袭人。 夜现天灯之瑞，日闻金石之音。 居民异之，乃因地以成其庙，后产灵芝之瑞，因号曰芝屿祖庙。 雍熙改元春正月丁卯，事告讫工。 檀越有河南方氏曰珏董之。
chunks.translated_text:
In the spring of the eighth year of Taiping Xingguo in the Song Dynasty (the year *guiwei*), no rain fell, and seeds remained unplanted in the earth, causing the stewards deep concern. In the second month, on the auspicious day *wuz*i, divination was performed before me. Before the old auspicious shrine lay a deep pool, its circumference spanning four or five *zhang*, its depths unfathomable. Suddenly, clouds and *qi* surged upward, lingering without dispersal the entire day. At dawn the following day, fierce winds, thunder, lightning, and hail arrived in unison, and the people rejoiced greatly.

Three days later, at first light, Zai Shengming came to the shrine to seek an answer. He beheld the shrine swept away, reduced to a ruin by floodwaters. Filled with astonishment and doubt, he prepared incense and submerged it in the pool, offering prayers. Suddenly, a wooden incense burner emerged from the water’s center, its ash unsullied by moisture—sure proof of a divine presence. In an instant, twin dragons coiled in the distance, bearing the shrine westward upon their wings, until they reached the islet where the mountains barred the stream’s flow. This islet was formerly called Incense Burner Peak. Crows and magpies took flight, calling as if to welcome something. Paper money marked the boundary, and a rare fragrance suffused the air. By night, the auspicious glow of heavenly lamps appeared; by day, the sound of metal and stone resounded. The villagers marveled and, seizing the opportunity, built a temple upon the site. Later, the temple produced the auspicious sign of *lingzhi*, and so it was named the Ancestral Temple of Zhi Islet.

In the first month of the first year of Yongxi, on the day *dingmao*, the construction was completed and the matter reported. The benefactor was a man of Henan surnamed Fang, named Jue, who oversaw the work.

chunks.original_text: 至乾道二年丙戌，珏之孙有曰询，曰感，曰仲，上其事於州牧冯公砺，扁以护境感应四字为额。 熙宁三年庚戌，河间章氏曰管，颖川陈氏曰彭初，济南林氏曰怀贤，江夏黄氏曰颁，以其事上於光禄卿程师孟，闻奏於朝。 适半山王氏当国，百姓困於青苗之役，未遑及此。 八年乙卯，郡人刘公彝知桂州，交趾寇边，陷钦、廉等州。 刘公恕，时同秋曹周公汝砺祷於予，予效公山之灵，寇果退。 刘公复具状以闻。 炎绍间，予之阴绩最为显着，韩忠武大仪镇之捷，武安和尚原之功。 本路安抚使薛公弼，保奏端平。 元年甲午，左藏周公说潮守周公燧，具条其事，上於执政李宗勉。 三年丙申十月，本路帅臣何公琮入除户部侍郎，始得旨。 嘉熙二年戊戌，命始下，敕封灵济，徽号有加，神喜人欢，用彰厥德。 自国朝以科目取士，予得以宰科名之籍。 乡之擢第者，横飞捷出，为诸邑之所敛衽南渡。 而后文风大振，胪传黄甲者有人，南宫高选者有人，声名翕翕，品秩犹高，或振节秋台，或具司禁帑，或出宰花封，或教分侯浮，至於一阶半级，可以车载斗量矣。 继之，以河南方氏珠曹曰策、王郎曰杰，各以文章取进士，是皆以梦卜於予而获报。 以此功德之在人也，甚博询之道听涂说，一朝一夕而然也。 庙自石晋开运以来，迄今数之，历甲子凡二千四百有奇。 初拆而为社坛，基於青布之演溪。 再迁而为巷东，即今灵济宫是也。 合门环眷，获宠天封：予，知证，九天金阙明道达德大仙显灵溥济真人，江王。 仲，知谔，九天玉阙宣化扶教上仙昭灵博济真人，饶王。 父，讳温，齐王，忠武真人。 母，田氏，仁寿仙妃。 予配陶氏，泾国夫人，顺助仁惠仙妃。 仲配许氏，卫国夫人，善助慈懿仙妃。 将五人：永安留守元帅查文徽，武安留守元帅边镐，节度使左监门元帅魏岑，都统使右监门元帅赵钟，都统军使先锋元帅刁彦能。 伯氏四人曰知诰，曰知询，曰知谏，曰知训，俱封王，庙食金陵。 其源流，世阅已备，见於五代史。 斯庙是作诸祠所祖，祖言始也，岂可忘其始而昧其所出哉。 祖庙创始履历，具述于前。 盖物久则坏，不修则愈坏。 木而堂之，石而室之，将为百千岁计。 其有功，浩费烦，檀越之布施名数，犹可考。 是岁在丁亥至元二十四年十一月丁未日也。 后一纪，复大门闾，榜其额曰：芝屿祖庙。 因旧碑泯没，予始降碑而铭之。 从河南方氏曰壮犹，曰逢午，曰嗣翕诸君之所请也。 铭曰： 水之流，穷其源。 木之叶，究其根。 源既深，流也分。 根既固，叶也蕃。 曰祖庙，祠是尊。 居此土，百千年。 功日月，德乾坤。 名与谥，史具存。 昔庙号，明而神。 今天爵，神而仙。 剑厥惠，泽乎民。 何以报，荐苹蘩。 岁丁亥，庙复新。 后一纪，大吾门。 铭于碑，石用鑴。 序犹始，祀有传。 效神岳，声三闻。 万万岁，祝圣君。 灵济宫记 予姓徐，出自赢姓。 栢医生若木，夏后氏封之於徐，其地下邳僮县是也。 国於夏殷周，咸有大功。 徐偃王治国，仁义着称，有获朱弓、赤矢之瑞。 周天子穆王闻之，伐徐。 徐不忍斗其民，去之彭城武原山之下，名其山曰徐，山居焉。 祖孙辈项，三千余年，名人魁士，载迹青史者，皆本於偃王，王予之祖也。
chunks.translated_text:
In the second year of Qiandao, *bingxu* (1166), Fang Jue’s grandsons—Xun, Gan, and Zhong—presented the matter to Prefect Feng Li of the prefecture, who inscribed the plaque with the four characters *Hujing Ganying* ("Protecting the Realm, Responding to Devotion"). In the third year of Xining, *gengxu* (1070), Zhang Guan of Hejian, Chen Pengchu of Yingchuan, Lin Huaixian of Jinan, and Huang Ban of Jiangxia reported the affair to Cheng Shimeng, Minister of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices, who memorialized the throne. At the time, the Wang clan of Banshan held power in the court, and the people were burdened by the *Green Sprouts* corvée, so the matter was not addressed.

In the eighth year, *yimao* (1075), when Liu Yi, a native of the prefecture, governed Guizhou, Jiaozhi raiders invaded the border and seized Qin and Lian prefectures. Liu Shu, then serving alongside Zhou Ruli in the autumn bureau, prayed to me, and I manifested the numinous power of Mount Gong. The raiders indeed retreated. Liu Shu then submitted a full report. During the Yanshao era, my hidden merits became most conspicuous: the victory of Han Zhongwu at Dayi Garrison and the achievements of Monk Yuan of Wu’an. Xue Bi, the Pacification Commissioner of the circuit, memorialized the throne during the Duanping era.

In the first year of Duanping, *jiawu* (1234), Zhou Shuo, Supervisor of the Left Treasury, and Zhou Sui, Prefect of Chaozhou, detailed the matter and submitted it to the chief minister Li Zongmian. In the third year, *bingshen* (1236), in the tenth month, He Cong, the military commissioner of the circuit, was appointed Vice Minister of the Ministry of Revenue, and the imperial decree was finally obtained. In the second year of Jiaxi, *wuxu* (1238), the edict was issued, bestowing the title *Lingji* ("Numinous Aid") and adding honorifics. The gods rejoiced, the people celebrated, and their virtue was thus made manifest.

Since the dynasty began selecting officials through the examination system, I have been enrolled in the register of successful candidates. Those from my hometown who passed the examinations soared like meteors, surpassing all other counties south of the river. Thereafter, the literary flourishing grew ever greater: those listed on the *Huangjia* (imperial examination roster) were numerous, as were those selected in the highest ranks of the Southern Palace. Their reputations resounded, their ranks were lofty—some held office in the autumn court, some oversaw the imperial treasury, some governed flowery domains, some instructed the floating lords. Even those with minor ranks could be counted by the cartload or measured by the bushel.

Later, Fang Ce of the Henan Fang clan, styled Zhu, and Wang Jie, styled Lang, each passed the imperial examinations through their literary talents. Both had divined their success through dreams at my shrine and received their reward. Such is the breadth of my merit among the people—far beyond the hearsay of idle gossip, achieved not in a single morning or evening.

Since the temple’s founding in the Kaiyun era of the Later Jin, counting the *jiazi* cycles, over two thousand four hundred years have passed. Initially dismantled to become a village altar, its foundation lay by the banks of Qingbu Stream. It was later relocated to the east of the lane, where the present Lingji Palace now stands. The entire household, encircled by devotion, received celestial favor and titles:

I, *Zhizheng*, was canonized as *Jiutian Jinque Mingdao Dade Dashian Xianling Puji Zhenren* ("Perceiver of Truth, Great Immortal of the Ninefold Golden Towers, Illuminating the Dao and Manifesting Virtue, Numinously Efficacious and Universally Beneficent Perfected One"), and enfeoffed as Jiang Wang.

Zhong, *Zhie*, was canonized as *Jiutian Yuque Xuanhua Fujiao Shangxian Zhaoling Bojie Zhenren* ("Perceiver of Righteousness, Supreme Immortal of the Ninefold Jade Towers, Propagating Transformation and Upholding the Teaching, Illustriously Numinous and Vastly Beneficent Perfected One"), and enfeoffed as Rao Wang.

Our father, named Wen, was enfeoffed as Qi Wang and canonized as *Zhongwu Zhenren* ("Loyal and Martial Perfected One").

Our mother, née Tian, was canonized as *Renshou Xianfei* ("Benevolent and Longevous Immortal Consort").

My wife, née Tao, was enfeoffed as *Jingguo Furen* ("Lady of Jing State") and canonized as *Shunzhu Renhui Xianfei* ("Compliant and Assisting, Benevolent and Kind Immortal Consort").

Zhong’s wife, née Xu, was enfeoffed as *Weiguo Furen* ("Lady of Wei State") and canonized as *Shanzhu Ciyi Xianfei* ("Kindly Assisting, Compassionate and Virtuous Immortal Consort").

Our five sons:
- **Chawen Hui**, *Yong’an Marshal and Guardian*, canonized as *Yuanshuai*.
- **Bian Hao**, *Wu’an Marshal and Guardian*, canonized as *Yuanshuai*.
- **Wei Cen**, *Military Commissioner and Left Gate Marshal*.
- **Zhao Zhong**, *Commander-in-Chief and Right Gate Marshal*.
- **Diao Yanneng**, *Commander of the Vanguard and Marshal of the Army*.

Our four elder brothers—*Zhigao*, *Zhixun*, *Zhijian*, and *Zhixun*—were all enfeoffed as kings and received sacrifices in the temples of Jinling. Their origins and generations are fully recorded in the *History of the Five Dynasties*. This temple is the progenitor of all such shrines. *Zu* ("ancestor") signifies a beginning—how could one forget the origin and obscure its source?

The founding and history of the Ancestral Temple have been recounted above. All things decay with time, and without repair, they decay further. Thus, we built halls of wood and chambers of stone, planning for a hundred thousand years. The merits were vast, the expenses great, and the names and contributions of the benefactors remain on record. This occurred in the year *dinghai* (1287), the twenty-fourth year of the Zhiyuan era, on the day *dingwei* of the eleventh month.

Twelve years later, the grand gate was restored, and the plaque was inscribed with the name *Zhiyu Zumiao* ("Ancestral Temple of Zhi Islet"). As the old stele had eroded, I descended this stele and inscribed it at the request of the gentlemen of the Henan Fang clan—Zhuangyou, Fengwu, and Sixi.

**Inscription:**
The waters flow—trace their source.
The leaves of trees—seek their root.
When the source runs deep, the streams diverge.
When the root stands firm, the leaves flourish.
This is the Ancestral Temple, revered shrine of this land.
Here it has stood for a hundred thousand years.
Its merit rivals the sun and moon, its virtue the heavens and earth.
Its names and titles are preserved in history.
Of old, its temple was called *Ming* ("Illustrious"), and the gods were divine.
Now, its celestial rank is that of immortal and transcendent.
Its blessings have been bestowed upon the people—
How shall we repay them? With offerings of orchids and ferns.
In the year *dinghai*, the temple was renewed.
Twelve years later, our gates were grandly restored.
Inscribed upon this stele, carved into stone,
Its origins recounted, its sacrifices transmitted.
Like the sacred peaks, its fame resounds thrice.
For ten thousand myriad years, we pray for the sagely lord.

**Record of Lingji Palace**
My surname is Xu, descended from the Ying clan. The physician Boyi of the Xia dynasty was enfeoffed in Xu, in the land of Xiapei Tong County. The state flourished through the Xia, Yin, and Zhou dynasties, each era marked by great merit. King Yan of Xu governed with such renown for benevolence and righteousness that he received the auspicious omen of a crimson bow and vermilion arrows. When King Mu of Zhou heard of this, he attacked Xu. Unwilling to let his people suffer, King Yan retreated to the foot of Wuyuan Mountain in Pengcheng, naming the mountain after himself. There he dwelled. For over three thousand years, generations of descendants—eminent figures and towering scholars whose deeds are recorded in history—all trace their lineage to King Yan, my ancestor.

chunks.original_text: 予家世仕唐，俱为大官。 五季之乱，豪杰猬起，瓜分幅裂，互相渔劫。 予奉天子命，留守金陵。 所管江南二十余州，泯征就宽，军给以饶。 林蛮洞蜓，守条死要。 秆耋嬉游，连手歌枢。 上无所怨，下无与雠。 江南之民，赖予以生。 予之功德，揭若日月。 虽世而下，无能磨灭。 晋开运之二年，闽王王氏失国，请命於予。 予提师万人，舰步并进。 闽之诸郡，各以城降。 踰年取福州，克之。 师抵峡江之南，道经青布。 乡之父老，壶浆以迎予师，而怨予曰：适有溃兵数百，隐匿於鳖峰之巅。 夸谩凶骄，将次为乱。 王师今日不至，颠覆朋邻，我余有几。 予乃引师南向，陆其峰，挫其锋，落其角距，歼厥渠魁，尽得其属人。 卒弃甲呼舞，不战而收。 乡民无怨，市买不变。 田之果谷，下无一迹。
chunks.translated_text:
My family served the Tang dynasty for generations, all holding high office. During the chaos of the Five Dynasties, heroes and warlords arose in swarms, carving up the land and plundering one another. By the Son of Heaven’s decree, I was left to guard Jinling. Overseeing more than twenty prefectures south of the Yangtze, I eased taxes and relaxed levies, ensuring the army was well-provisioned. The tribes of the forests and caves adhered to the laws, holding fast to their oaths even unto death. The elderly and children played and wandered, joining hands to sing in celebration. Above, none bore grievance; below, none harbored enmity. The people of the Jiangnan region owed their lives to me. My merit and virtue shone as brightly as the sun and moon—though ages may pass, they cannot be erased.

chunks.original_text: 於龙首之东，丰衍端夷，山水俱秀，卜予得吉，而宅之。 乌鹊假灵，蜂蛇交集。 纸钱结界，异香袭人。 夜现天灯之瑞，日闻金石之音。 乡人因之，以成其庙。 乃征土木石工，执器备用，来会祠下。 斩板斡聋柱础，陶□臂筑垣墉。 岁在政和之丁酉，工逸事遂。 作貌显严，集然而威。 至今故老相传，尚能记亿其事。 阐而辟之，殿宇深邃，则隆兴。 改元癸未之秋，增而广之，庖库廓大。 则开禧二年丙寅之春，堂庭建植，阶序整齐。 巍巍乎其高，炳炳乎其新。 规模程度，将多於前功。 则岁在壬申咸淳之八年也，至今檀越姓名，书於梁者，犹未泯没。 我思古人，实获我心，时我亦不敢宁於厥居，以保其子孙黎民，亦职有利哉。 若夫西、南、北等处祠像，皆本於此。 拆而分之，岁月久矣。 有能质於鲐背观齿之夫，则见予之灵德入人也深。 靖康阳九之厄，予以神兵护国，效公山草木之灵，显旗蠢旎麾之相。 孽寇就诛，中原底定。 予之功绩，闻奏朝廷。 已蒙圣恩，南渡不果。

chunks.original_text: 嘉熙间，乡人潮守周公燧，以父老章少白等状，再请於朝。 金书褒奖，勑封灵济徽号，焕然祝册於庙，祭式有加。 神人俱喜，伟欤盛哉。 迩来时异事殊，中泽之鸿甫集。 至於庙事，奚暇及此。 上冠下屦，谁其正之。 圮桷腐瓦，谁其易之。 墙壁阴剥，图像默昧，谁其整之。 予若不扬其烈，大降显於四方，历告於尔有众，则曰甚。 一日堕饭不顾，将安以为揭虔妥灵之地乎。 乡人各以事卜於予，求其笔以验其事。 予示之以谶曰：签签六十有四象，《易》之六十四卦。 天地万物莫出乎《易》。 《易》为卜筮之书，定之以吉凶，所以断也。 既示之以签用，敢援笔为文，以委而任，司尔众，其惟致告：自今至於后日，各恭尔职，各设中於乃心，经之营之，立定厥功。 使弊者复兴，故者复新。 予亦不敢独专其美，安生兴事，民业有经。 俾以寿而富，俾以炽而昌，予之休庇於人者，亦不浅。 秋八月吉日庚戌，工告讫功，请记於予。 予王父相吴，封齐王，谥曰忠武。 伯氏四人：长讳知诰，世袭父爵，改封於唐。 次讳知询、知谏、知训，俱秉吴政封王，各庙食金陵。 予曰知证，封江王。 仲氏曰知夸，封饶王。 事载之史，所有阴绩，着於《尚书□ 祠部》庙。 食兹土，已四百余年，将以至于千千年，未可计也。 恭遇圣朝一统，率土称臣。 天地鬼神，克享其德。 仰冀圣恩，俯颁宣命。 嘉兹荣宠，式副所期，(亩十犬)亩不忘。 三呼皇帝万岁，万岁，万万岁。 辞曰： 婉婉偃王，孝孙有庆。 维德不爽，居此一方。 蜿蜓鳖峰，龙首之东。 灵济褒封，於民有功。 新庙奕奕，厥声赫赫。 肩臑陌骼，来享来格。 尔民不詑，降福既多。 矢辞以歌，纪石不磨。 碑阴辨 或谓碑记，有阴无阴。 吾不知记为何，碑为何。 所谓无阴之记，则乐记、学记、史记、丧记、传记、是也。 既刻於而，则谓之碑。 如碑用词用铭，皆伤悲之文，记则无之。 昔柳宗元为父作石表，犹有阴书其弟子、门人姓名。 表阴自柳侯始，记阴自徐江王始，谁敢议耶。 碑阴 天之未丧斯文，故假手於我，用德以彰厥善，惟尔之能予其懋简相尔。 今林东村公所举周君壮翕之言曰：今将生申乎，将生尹乎。 旨哉斯言也，以代予言者也。 刻之座右，使为士者登斯堂，读斯记，其尚知所勉焉，毋作神羞。 又 生为人，死为神。 有功於国，有德於民者，宜有庙祀。 有庙祀而有勑命者，必有碑碣以记其事。 昔柳侯降为罗池之神，有韩文公为记。 予虽效柳侯之万一，愧无柳侯之才，不得韩文公记之，何以示来者。 予敢自序履历，后文公者，记之可矣。 存诚记 灵济之庭，字其额曰存诚。 此神笔也。 一日客自远方来，而有假灵之请，枢衣而进於堂上，得神之所作碑铭记赞，熟而读之，俨然若思。 趁而退曰：何独存诚二字，缺其文，毋乃有之而未之刻耶。 请质於予。 予神也，不能以口谕，姑假笔舌为言，而复之曰：夫诚者，真实无妄之谓也。 人之常性，未始不诚，不诚无以立身。 君臣之间，此诚也。 父子之间，此诚也。 昆弟、夫妇、朋友之间，此诚也。 诚一而已，盍求诸身而诚者存。 初非所谓诚之道也，人能於此勉力为之，虽雷霆於上而不之惧，渊谷于下而不之恐，此无他诚存故也。
chunks.translated_text:
During the Jiaxi era, the local prefect of Chaozhou, Zhou Sui, along with village elders Zhang Shaobai and others, submitted a petition to the court. A rescript in gold ink bestowed praise, conferring the honorific title *Lingji* upon me, and the temple’s sacrificial register was splendidly renewed, its rites further augmented. Both gods and men rejoiced—how grand and glorious!

Yet of late, times have changed and affairs diverged; the swans of the central marsh have but newly alighted. As for the temple’s upkeep, who has leisure for such matters? The roof’s crown is askew, the foundation’s sandals unaligned—who will set them right? The walls crumble in shadow, the murals dim and obscure—who will restore them? If I do not exalt my illustrious deeds, widely manifesting them to the four quarters and proclaiming them to all of you, it would be remiss indeed. Should even a single meal be neglected, how could this remain a place of reverence and divine tranquility?

The villagers each consulted me on their affairs, seeking my brush to validate their fortunes. I revealed to them the oracle, saying: *The sixty-four slips correspond to the sixty-four hexagrams of the* Yijing. *Nothing in heaven or earth lies beyond the* Yijing. *As a book of divination, it determines fortune and misfortune—thus it decides all.* Having shown them the slips’ use, how could I dare take up my brush to compose a text, entrusting and charging you all? Let this be my proclamation: from this day forward, each of you must attend to your duties, setting the mean within your hearts. Plan and labor to establish your merits, that the ruined may be revived, the old made new.

I dare not claim sole credit for this glory; in initiating such affairs, the people’s livelihoods must be ordered. May they prosper in longevity and wealth, flourish and thrive—my blessings upon them are not slight. On an auspicious day in the eighth month, the autumn of the gengxu year, the work was completed, and I was asked to inscribe this record.

My royal grandfather ruled Wu and was enfeoffed as Prince of Qi, posthumously honored as *Zhongwu*. He had four elder brothers: the eldest, named Zhigao, inherited his father’s title and was later re-enfeoffed in Tang. The next, Zhixun, Zhijian, and Zhixun, all held power in Wu, were enfeoffed as princes, and each received temple sacrifices in Jinling. I am Zhizheng, enfeoffed as Prince of Jiang. My second brother, Zhikua, was enfeoffed as Prince of Rao. These events are recorded in history, and my hidden merits are detailed in the *Book of [Missing Character]*, under the *Bureau of Sacrifices*. I have partaken of this land’s offerings for over four hundred years, and shall continue for a thousand thousand more—beyond reckoning.

In this sagely dynasty’s era of unity, all within the realm offer allegiance. Heaven and earth, ghosts and spirits, all partake of its virtue. Humbly awaiting the imperial grace, I look up to the throne’s decree. May this honor and favor meet expectations, and may the people never forget. Thrice I cry: *Long live the emperor! Long live the emperor! Ten thousand years, ten thousand, ten thousand years!*

**Eulogy:**
*Gentle and yielding, the Prince of Yan,*
*His filial descendants are blessed.*
*Unfailing in virtue,*
*He dwells in this land.*
*By winding Biefeng, east of Dragon’s Head,*
*The Lingji title bestowed—his merit to the people.*
*The new temple stands resplendent,*
*Its renown mighty and bright.*
*Shoulder to shoulder, the people gather,*
*Coming to offer and partake.*
*You, the people, do not doubt—*
*Abundant blessings descend.*
*I pledge this ode,*
*Carved in stone, unyielding.*

**On the Stele’s Reverse:**
Some say stele inscriptions must have a reverse side, while records need not. I know not what defines a *record* or a *stele*. Those called *records* without a reverse—such as the *Record of Music*, *Record of Learning*, *Records of History*, *Mourning Records*, *Biographies*—are not steles. Once engraved on stone, it is called a *stele*. Steles employ *ci* and *ming*, both mournful texts, while records do not. Long ago, Liu Zongyuan composed a stone inscription for his father, yet still inscribed the names of his disciples and followers on the reverse. The reverse of a *biao* began with Liu; the reverse of a *record* began with Xu, Prince of Jiang—who would dare question it?

**Stele’s Reverse:**
Heaven has not yet forsaken this culture, thus it lends me its hand to glorify virtue and illuminate goodness. It is your duty to assist me in this endeavor.

Recently, Lin Dongcun’s public assembly presented the words of Zhou Junxi: *"Shall we give birth to a Shen, or to a Yin?"* How profound! These words speak for me. Let them be carved at your side. When scholars ascend this hall and read this record, may they know what to strive for, and never bring shame upon the gods.

**Further:**
In life, one is a man; in death, a spirit. Those who serve the state and benefit the people deserve temple sacrifices. Temples with imperial decrees must have steles to record their deeds. Long ago, Liu Hou was demoted to the god of Luo Pool, and Han Wengong composed a record for him. Though I have emulated but a fraction of Liu Hou’s deeds, I lack his talent and cannot secure a Han Wengong to inscribe my story. How then shall I instruct posterity? I dare recount my own history; let those who come after Han Wengong record it.

**Record of Upholding Sincerity:**
The hall of Lingji bears the inscription *Cuncheng* ("Upholding Sincerity")—this is the god’s own brush. One day, a guest from afar arrived, seeking to borrow my numen. Clad in ceremonial robes, he entered the hall and found the god’s compositions—steles, inscriptions, records, and eulogies. Reading them carefully, he pondered deeply before withdrawing and asking: *"Why are only the two characters* Cuncheng *left uninscribed? Is it that they exist but remain uncarved?"* He sought my answer.

I, a spirit, cannot speak with my mouth, so I borrow brush and tongue to reply: *Sincerity is truth without falsehood. Human nature is inherently sincere; without sincerity, one cannot establish oneself. Between ruler and minister—this is sincerity. Between father and son—this is sincerity. Among brothers, husband and wife, friends—this is sincerity. Sincerity is one and the same; seek it within yourself, and it will endure. This is not the so-called* Way of Sincerity. *If one strives in this, though thunder roars above, one will not fear; though abysses yawn below, one will not tremble. There is no other reason—sincerity abides.*

chunks.original_text: 夫苟一言之不真，一语之不实，曰妄也，非诚也。 甚矣、暗室之中，视如无人，手指目视，洞见肺腑。 诚之存者几希，其曰妄者滔滔皆是。 臣如是以事其君，而君疑。 子如是以口其父，而父疑。 至於昆弟、朋友、夫妇如是以相从事，则无往而不之疑。 机心一萌，鸥乌飞而不下，况於人乎，况於鬼神乎。 子不以自欺，真实而无妄者也，虽不言诚，而诚自存。 何文之有，《易》曰：闲邪存诚。 二字之义，其始於此，子知之乎耳，盍记诸。 亲睦堂记 亲睦堂记，所以明人伦也。 人之大伦，亲亲为大。 亲亲者也，父父也，子子也，兄兄也，弟弟也，夫夫也，妇妇也。 故周官太宰以八统诏王驭万民，其一曰亲亲。 诚以父父，子子，兄兄，弟弟，夫夫，妇妇，其为人伦也大。 此太宰之驭万民，必先以亲亲言之。 亲亲者，教民之本也。 三代盛时，人伦明於上，小民亲於下，孝、慈、友、悌，辑睦和逊。 不待其习与性成，是亦圣人之教，不肃而成者也。 自秦、汉而下，其治，一切出於便利，而不耿无礼。 古先圣人所谓教民相亲睦者，悉置而不讲。 此纲常所以不立，礼义所以不明，而天下所以日趁於奸行，不可制其弊。 至於父子不同居，兄弟不相容，教化离绝，国俗伤败，而天下无复知有亲之义矣。 是以古之民也醇，今之民也诈； 古之民也厚，今之民也薄。 是岂今之民不如古之民哉。 必有圣人者出，如尧、舜，如禹、汤，如文、武、周公、孔子，承其厚而维之，使为父子、兄弟、夫妇者，知其所以为父子、兄弟、夫妇之义，庶几上古之风，吾於今日复见之矣。 兹者伏遇圣朝一统，以仁率下。 圣言宣布，首以孝顺为民劝，许令乡里申举以闻。

If but a single word is untrue, a single phrase insincere, it is called delusion—it is not sincerity. How grave it is! In the darkest chamber, though one sees no one, every gesture, every glance, lays bare the heart’s depths. Those in whom sincerity abides are few indeed; those who speak falsely flow like a torrent. If a minister thus serves his lord, the lord will doubt. If a son thus speaks to his father, the father will doubt. When brothers, friends, husband and wife interact in such a manner, there is nowhere doubt does not arise. Once the mind of calculation sprouts, even gulls and crows will not alight—how much less men, how much less spirits and gods?

You, who do not deceive yourself, are true and without falsehood. Though you do not speak of sincerity, sincerity abides of itself. What need is there for ornamentation? The *Book of Changes* says: *"Guard against deceit to preserve sincerity."* The meaning of these two characters begins here. Do you understand? Remember this well.

**Record of the Hall of Familial Harmony**
The *Record of the Hall of Familial Harmony* serves to clarify human relationships. Among the great bonds of humanity, none is greater than loving one’s kin. To love one’s kin is for the father to be a father, the son to be a son, the elder brother to be an elder brother, the younger brother to be a younger brother, the husband to be a husband, the wife to be a wife. Thus, in the *Rites of Zhou*, the Grand Steward instructed the king to govern the myriad people through eight principles, the first of which was *"cherish one’s kin."*

Truly, for the father to be a father, the son a son, the elder brother an elder brother, the younger brother a younger brother, the husband a husband, the wife a wife—this is the foundation of human relationships. This is why the Grand Steward, in governing the myriad people, must first speak of cherishing one’s kin. Cherishing one’s kin is the root of teaching the people.

In the flourishing eras of the Three Dynasties, human relationships were clear among the high, and the common folk were harmonious below. Filial piety, kindness, fraternal love, and deference were practiced in harmony and humility. This was not a matter of cultivation or innate nature—it was the teaching of the sages, achieved without sternness.

From the Qin and Han onward, governance relied entirely on expediency, heedless of propriety. The ancient sages’ teachings on fostering kinship among the people were entirely abandoned. Thus, the great principles of order were not established, rites and righteousness were not illuminated, and the world daily descended into deceitful conduct, its ills beyond remedy. Fathers and sons no longer dwelt together, brothers could not tolerate one another, moral instruction was severed, and the customs of the state were corrupted, until the world no longer knew the meaning of kinship.

Thus, the people of antiquity were pure; the people of today are cunning. The people of antiquity were sincere; the people of today are shallow. Is it that the people of today are inferior to those of old? Only if a sage like Yao or Shun, like Yu or Tang, like King Wen, King Wu, the Duke of Zhou, or Confucius were to arise, upholding and preserving their virtue, so that fathers and sons, brothers, husbands and wives might understand the meaning of their roles—only then might the customs of high antiquity be glimpsed again in our time.

Now, under the unified sagely court, governance is guided by benevolence. The sagely words are proclaimed, with filial piety and obedience foremost among the virtues encouraged for the people. Villages and towns are permitted to recommend those who exemplify these virtues, that they may be known.

chunks.original_text: 神灵欢喜，踊跃叹呀。 四方闻风，靡然自化。 或有以贞节称，或有以节妇着。 义门孝坊，在在有人。 奈此拜若罔闻，知污俗未变，为神之羞。 神於此时，不容嘿嘿。 乃命乡人，修茸斯堂。 於殿东，以奉神之族属焉，亲其所亲，故榜之曰亲睦堂。 使有事於庙者，登斯堂，瞻斯像，亲睦之心，可以油然而生矣。 堂成而为之记，所以明人伦也。 继自今，为父者慈而教，为子者孝而箴，为兄者友而恭，为弟者敬而顺，为夫者和而义，为妇者柔而正。 勉哉，勉哉，庶无愧斯堂之名。 至元甲午，惟三月癸丑朔。 鳖峰敬仙灵济真人记。 又 灵济宫正殿之东有堂，扁其额曰亲睦。 客有儒其人者，摄齐升堂而请问曰：亲睦者，得非坊记所谓睦於父母之党，曰亲者乎。 予曰：然。 又曰：上至曾祖，下至玄孙，此为父之党乎。 予复曰：然。 又曰：母之兄弟为舅，母之从兄弟为从舅，此为母之党乎。 予复曰：然。 客乃叹曰：人生天地间，为物之灵，其所以异於禽兽，以其知有父母之党之亲者也。 如其知有父母之党之亲，亲则睦矣。 以亲睦二子而闻知於人者，是诚奚心哉。 予曰：善哉。 子知之乎，今之世俗，以智诈相，尚亡制度，弃礼义，捐廉耻，其知有睦於父母之党之亲，吾斯之未能信。 自南陕废，而孝友之道缺矣。 棠棣废，而兄弟之情绝矣。 宜尔子孙蛰蛰兮，谁复咏蠡斯之德之子。 于归宜其室家，谁复歌桃夭之诗。 既有肥羜以速诸父，既有肥牡以速诸舅，谁复诵伐木之章。 孟子曰：无辞让之心，非人也。 是以吾心汲汲於所欲，为不容嘿嘿。 以秦人视越人之肥瘠，不加忧戚於其心。 为今之说，必寓之於书，宣之於口，以古。 谕之。 庶几人心天理，一脉如线，绵绵延延，犹有可续可救之道。 此古人之所谓化。 当世莫若言传，来世莫若书。 然观古人苟得其时而行其道，则无所谓书，亦无所谓言。 言之者，盖有不得已者矣。 客曰：诚如是也。

The spirits rejoice, leaping and exclaiming in delight. Hearing of this from all directions, the people naturally transform themselves. Some are renowned for their chastity and fidelity, others for their virtuous widowhood. Gates of righteousness and arches of filial piety stand everywhere, each with its exemplars. Yet despite these offerings, the gods remain as if unhearing—knowing the customs remain corrupt, this brings shame upon the divine. The spirits cannot remain silent at such a time. They command the villagers to repair this hall. To the east of the main hall, a chamber is built to honor the kin of the gods, cherishing those they hold dear. Thus, it is named the Hall of Kinship and Harmony. When those who come to the temple ascend this hall, gaze upon these images, the heart of kinship and harmony may naturally arise within them.

The hall is completed, and this record is made to illuminate human relationships. From this day forward, let fathers be kind and instructive, let sons be filial and admonishing; let elder brothers be friendly and respectful, let younger brothers be reverent and obedient; let husbands be harmonious and righteous, let wives be gentle and upright. Strive on, strive on—may you not be unworthy of this hall’s name.

In the third month, the first day of the gui-chou, the jia-wu year of the Zhiyuan era.

*Record of the Divine and Efficacious Perfected Lord Jingxian of Biefeng.*

---

Moreover, to the east of the main hall of the Divine Efficacy Palace stands a hall, its plaque inscribed with the words *Kinship and Harmony*. A scholar, gathering his robes and ascending the hall, inquired: "Does *kinship and harmony* not refer to what the stele inscription calls ‘harmony with the kin of father and mother’—that is, one’s relatives?"

I replied: "Indeed."

He continued: "From great-grandfather down to great-grandson—are these not the kin of the father?"

I again replied: "Indeed."

He further asked: "The mother’s brothers are called uncles, and the mother’s cousins are called maternal cousins—are these not the kin of the mother?"

I again replied: "Indeed."

The scholar then sighed and said: "Man, born between heaven and earth, is the most spiritually endowed of creatures. What distinguishes him from birds and beasts is his knowledge of the kinship of his father’s and mother’s kin. If one knows the kinship of one’s father’s and mother’s kin, then harmony follows. Yet if one must rely on these two words—*kinship and harmony*—to be known among others, what is the true intent behind this?"

I said: "Well said! Do you understand? In today’s world, customs are governed by cunning and deceit, neglecting proper order, abandoning ritual and righteousness, discarding integrity and shame. That people still know harmony with the kin of their father and mother—I cannot yet believe it. Since the decline of the southern and northern courts, the way of filial piety and brotherly love has been lost. The *Tangdi* ode is forgotten, and the bonds of brotherhood are severed. Who still chants the *Lisi* ode, praising the virtue of descendants? Who still sings the *Taoyao* poem, celebrating the bride who brings harmony to her household? When fat lambs are prepared to hasten the arrival of uncles, when plump bulls are offered to welcome maternal kin—who still recites the *Famu* ode? Mencius said: ‘One without a heart of deference and yielding is not human.’ Thus, my heart is restless with what I desire, for silence is not permissible. To the people of Qin, the plumpness or leanness of the people of Yue stirs no concern in their hearts. Therefore, today’s discourse must be inscribed in writing, proclaimed in speech, and grounded in antiquity to enlighten them. Perhaps then the heavenly principle in human hearts—though as tenuous as a thread—may yet be unbroken, continuous, and still possess a way to be preserved and restored. This is what the ancients called *transformation*.

For the present age, nothing surpasses verbal transmission; for future generations, nothing surpasses the written word. Yet if the ancients had lived in a time when their Way could be practiced, there would have been no need for writing or speech. Speech arises only from necessity."

The scholar said: "Truly, it is so."

chunks.original_text: 今之所言曰圣父，曰圣母，曰圣兄，此神之亲也，其得於南陕棠棣之意欤。 曰圣子，曰圣侄，曰圣孙，至於曰圣舅，曰圣婿者，亦神之亲也，其又得於螽斯、伐木、桃夭之意欤。 虽然神之所谓亲者，仆固知其为父母之党之亲，亲则神之亲也，其如世俗何。 予曰：固哉，愚也。 子之所举坊记为问，予以为子之好学通於记者，所有《大学》格言，曾之学乎。 复坐，吾语汝《大学》曰，欲治其国，先齐其家。 又曰：一家仁，则一国兴。 仁仁者，所以亲亲其亲也。 亲亲以睦，其为仁之本欤。 故君子笃於亲，则民兴於仁，未有仁而遗其亲者也。 客曰：唯。 而起请记之。 燕喜堂记 含章贞一者，夫人之德也。 从容和缓者，夫人之言也。 旦夕忧勤为烯为绤者，夫人之功也。 环姿律态盛矣，丽矣，视之俨然不可胜赞者，夫人之容也。 此四教者，美夫人也，配食庙庭者宜也。 庙庭之西，有堂翼然，而临於上者，燕喜堂也。 燕喜堂者，夫人祠也。 载瞻其祠，有人如玉，华裾长袖，绮绣文章，缀明珠而载金翠，喜堂人像也。 左右森严，或行或止，或坐或起者，宜鬟者，开妆镜者，执巾栉者，涂脂而抹粉者，侍人也。 曰修仪，曰昭仪，曰修容，曰容华，曰昭华，曰顺成者，侍人之号也。 曰典妇功，曰典系枲，曰女府，曰女史，曰女祝，曰女御者，侍人之职也。 受藏之府者，内府也。 受用之府者，外府也。 府者，库也。 乃曰莞库，曰度支，曰掌帐籍者，侍人之责也。 至若罗幔垂，而香风鼓舞，丝帘卷，而淡月朦胧，凭栏一叹，更有庭花野草相间而青红者。 堂中之景致，灯烛辉煌，椒兰芬芳，杯盘狼籍，八珍罗乎其前者，夫人宴也。 既宴既醉，满堂欣欣，相酬相酢，而且笑且语者，六宫圣眷同其乐也。 神乐而人亦乐，人乐而神降之福也。 岁青伏、腊，人之祀於此者，答神麻也。 至於求嗣者，则有注子孙司，专掌其任也。 亲抱送者，并是天上之麒麟也。 呜呼，夫人之德，之美、之灵者，凛乎其清，昭昭乎其明，濯濯乎其声。 可敬可畏，可爱，可慕，民无得而称也，必有曹大家者为之史也，又有卫夫人者为之书也。 予所记者，燕喜堂事也。 堂曰燕喜者，取《诗》所谓鲁侯燕喜颂也。 斋堂灵济宫记 自观察使常公设立乡学而后，闽之士风始振。 曩时，此地有修竹茂松，西围周密，又有江水之萦回，山坡之拱抱，风土最为奇特。 人之读书为士者，因而於此创立小学，命名曰斋。 斋之中有讲学焉，非董马名辈，不敢下惟而施绛帐也。 上而接武，下而布武，楫逊之礼，粲然可观。 旧有神祠，在堂之东，序曰：地主非所谓能以祸福动人者，之为神也。 一遭巢寇，再遇闽兵，斋庐随废，堂亦无存。 加以王政之烦苛，民生几绝，故人之为士者，降而为农，或又降而为工、商，至今闻者，莫不为之太息。 幸而北主之祠，香火不灭，见者恻然，彷彷而不忍去。 遂斩茅为屋，聊避风雨而已。 庆历年间，乡人敦岊等，始盖以瓦，像而木之。 后岁甲一周过半，陈知足等乃以石为柱，其为规模，宏且远矣。 又得檀越京教周公毅，将仕周世修，周公崇诸人，乐施尔赀，用成厥志。 目今石柱题名，犹有可考。 工既就，尊其祠曰庙。 以其未有徽称，请予就其位，以为民主。

Once, it bore the title "Responsive to Devotion"; now, it is called "Numinous Aid"—such is the origin of its name. Yet what I speak of is not some power to sway men with fortune or misfortune, nor can I escape the duty of giving voice to its story. Though its shrine’s construction may be grand, surpassing that of former times, it is still insufficient to stir the gaze of later generations. Thus, we undertook a thorough renovation: repainting in five colors, sculpting the divine images, adorning them with yellow curtains and vermilion tables, lending them a measure of solemn dignity. By reckoning the years, this was the fifth year of Xianchun, in the cyclical year *jisi* (1269).

Alas! Man is the most spirited of all creatures, and who does not know the love of parents, cherishing them all their lives? Yet when it comes to ancestors, that love fades and is forgotten—how much more so for those of higher generations? Those who till the land, labor as artisans or merchants, or even aspire to be scholars, ought to trace the origins of their forebears, restoring their legacy rather than dismissing it as a relic of the past, fit only for idle chatter in some book-lined study. Though all who read and grasp the principles of virtue may be called scholars, I dare not compare ordinary men to the likes of Yi Yin, who rose from the fields of Shen, or Fu Yue, who was discovered while building walls—these were sages of their age. Even the emperors of the Han, who won the realm from horseback, welcomed the counsel of peddlers and butchers, inscribing their merits on bronze tripods and recording their names in history. How could such achievements be the sole province of those who read and understand the Dao?

In my humble view, when the Qin dynasty brought ruin, men took refuge in obscurity to preserve their lives. But today, the state nurtures scholars through education, summons the worthy by edict, and sets forth clear paths for advancement. Whether one is a farmer, artisan, or merchant, all may be drawn upward to become scholars. Thus, I dare to set down this account, to encourage those who would follow that path. Some may call this hall a village study, a place for warming the *Li Ke* sacrifices—such talk is but the prattle of rustics from Qi’s eastern wilds; pay it no heed.

In the third year of the *Dade* reign (1299), on the auspicious day of the mid-autumn month, the *Shefeng* Mountain Recluse wrote this. *Composed on behalf of the Elder of Dong Village, the Record of the Numinous Aid Palace.*

chunks.original_text: 岁癸巳之夏，五桂龙与沈建翁、周仝、周用、明林椿、郭泳翁、郑汝显七人，共谋而葺之，而卜於神。 维神显相，化笔为文，以委而任，输奂一新。 八月功成，再降之笔，序以履历，而为之记。 示之以吉凶，而为之卦。 劝之以忠信礼义，而为之文赋。 读之一言一话，皆以孔孟垂世立教之心为心。 此聪明正直之神也，虽班孟坚西京之笔，左太冲三都之文，杨子云五祚之手，与夫芝房宝鼎之歌，黄马碧圭之卞，未可及也。 有神如此，乌得而忽。 诸章君七人，奉词惟谨，敬以神所作之记，刻於石焉。 里人林迪功延年书之，属予篆其额。 十二月，以神所而赐古诗来曰：碑既立矣，今日之事，君记之，此神之意也。 予未暇作笔，再赐以古今诗一篇，六十五通。 有曰：记在名俱在，子忘神不忘之句。 子不敢辞，为之记其词曰：昔有祀兮，今有传。 昔有勑兮，今有宣。 古。 为文兮，劝以贤。 庙重新兮，事已完。 曰雨旸兮，感二天。 民祈祷兮，心益虔。 聋兹铭兮，垂万年。 世不忘兮，德无迁。 余庆堂道场记 如是我闻。 佛有偈曰：万物本於心，於心何处寻。 所以者何，曰：即心是佛。 佛也者，释云：弗，人也。 弗是人，则体相无耳。 常实，无真，无相，无忍，无妨，无实，无去来，无有挂碍，如是，如是，即无所有安顿。 那处是人不解，能於心上究竟到尽，佛无时不在。 苟其心不然，徒以口学虚谈般若，假名引导，贪利罔功，甚次。 大千俱坏，况於我佛一道场乎。 景德祥符而后，佛之功行，着闻天下，在在处处，设立道场，各绘塑佛像，香火而钦奉之。 吾乡余庆堂，亦一道场也。 自开禧丙寅，至元贞丙申，以羲历策之，其数得九十有奇。 年未踰远，何道场之坏，大不如昔。 上漏傍穿，煣温不除。
chunks.translated_text:
In the summer of the guisi year, Zhang Guilong, along with Shen Jianweng, Zhou Quan, Zhou Yong, Ming Linchun, Guo Yongweng, and Zheng Ruxian—seven men in all—jointly resolved to restore the temple and consulted the deities through divination. The gods manifested their presence, transforming brushstrokes into script, entrusting the task to them and renewing the edifice in radiant splendor. By the eighth month, the work was completed, and the deities again descended through the brush, recounting their deeds in sequence to compose this record. They revealed fortune and misfortune through hexagrams, exhorted loyalty, trust, ritual, and righteousness through prose and verse. Every word and phrase echoed the intent of Confucius and Mencius in their teachings for the ages. Such are the gods—wise, luminous, and upright—that even the brush of Ban Mengjian in the Western Capital, the *Three Capitals* of Zuo Taichong, the *Five Blessings* of Yang Ziyun, or the odes to sacred mushrooms and precious tripods, the hymns of yellow steeds and jade tablets, cannot compare. With gods so manifest, how could one dare to neglect them? The seven gentlemen, Zhang and his companions, reverently received the deities’ words and inscribed the record upon stone. The local scholar Lin Digong Yannian transcribed it, while I was entrusted with engraving the title in seal script.

In the twelfth month, the deities bestowed an ancient poem, saying: *"The stele now stands—today’s affair is for you to record, for such is the will of the gods."* Before I could take up my brush, they granted another poem, this one spanning ancient and modern times, sixty-five stanzas in all. Among them were the lines: *"Where the record endures, so too does the name; you may forget, but the gods do not."* I dared not refuse and thus composed this account of their words:

*Of old, there were sacrifices—now, there is transmission.*
*Of old, there were decrees—now, there is proclamation.*
*Ancient writings exhort to virtue.*
*The temple stands renewed, its affairs complete.*
*Rain and shine respond to the dual heavens.*
*The people pray with ever-deepening reverence.*
*This inscription I carve to endure ten thousand years.*
*May the world never forget, for virtue knows no change.*

**Record of the Yüqìng Hall Daoist Sanctuary**

Thus have I heard. The Buddha has a gatha:
*"All things arise from the mind—where in the mind are they sought?"*
And why? Because *"the mind itself is Buddha."*
What is Buddha? The *Shi* explains: *Fu* means "person."
If not for the person, there would be no embodied form.
Eternally real, without truth, without form,
Without patience, without hindrance, without substance,
Without coming or going, without entanglement—
Thus, thus, there is nothing to be settled.
Where is the person who does not understand?
One who exhaustively investigates the mind will find
The Buddha present at all times.
If the mind is otherwise, mere recitation of prajñā,
Empty talk, false guidance, greed for gain, and deceitful merit—
These are far inferior.
Even when the great chiliocosm crumbles,
How much less can the Buddha’s single sanctuary endure?

Since the Jingde and Xiangfu eras, the Buddha’s meritorious deeds have been renowned throughout the world. In every place, Daoist sanctuaries were established, each adorned with painted and sculpted Buddha images, revered with incense and offerings. Our village’s Yüqìng Hall is one such sanctuary. From the Kaixi bingyin year to the Yuanzhen bingshen year, reckoned by the Xia calendar, ninety-odd years have passed. Though not so distant in time, why has the sanctuary fallen into such disrepair, far inferior to its former state? Its roof leaks, its walls are breached, and damp rot lingers unaddressed.
